DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States met in emergency session at the request of Panamanian ambassador Jose Maria Cabrera, a holdover from Noriega's regime. He told the gathering, ``Under no circumstances will we accept some supposed leaders who are puppets imposed by the United States,'' referring to the provisional government headed by Guillermo Endara and recognized by the Bush administration. Endara asked the OAS in a letter to recognize Lawrence Chewning Fabrega as his designated representative but the members decided to recognize Cabrera, instead. Peru withdrew its ambassador to the United States in protest ``until the invading troops withdraw,'' according to a statement from the Peruvian embassy. Bush, laying out the reasons for the military action, cited Noriega's declaration last Friday of a state of war, the slaying of an American officer last Saturday and the manhandling of an American serviceman and his wife. ``Gen. Noriega's reckless threats and attacks upon Americans in Panama created an imminent danger to the 35,000 American citizens in Panama,'' Bush said. ``As president, I have no higher obligation than to safeguard the lives of American citizens. ``And that is why I directed our armed forces to protect the lives of American citizens in Panama and bring Gen. Noriega to justice in the United States.'' With Noriega on the run, Bush said the United States was lifting economic sanctions against Panama and freeing Panamanian assets frozen in U.S. banks. Baker said Bush decided Sunday to use force against Noriega. After that decision was made, Baker said, the United States received intelligence reports that Noriega might launch a commando attack against Americans in an urban residential neighborhood. While saying it was unclear whether the report was reliable, Baker told reporters that if Americans had been killed or terrorized, ``you would be asking us today, `Why didn't you act to prevent this kind of violence against our citizens.''' The secretary added, ``I'm not going to tell you that the crisis in Panama has been totally resolved. ... But Manuel Noriega, who was yesterday's `maximum leader' is today's hunted fugitive.'' Ever since Noriega was indicted in Florida on drug-trafficking charges in February 1988, the United States has been trying to force him from power through economic sanctions and diplomatic pressure. The Soviet Union condemned the action, saying the United States ``must immediately stop its armed intervention.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher praised it as ``a courageous decision'' and said, ``Someone has to uphold democracy.'' Former President Ronald Reagan, who had unsuccessfully tried to force Noriega from power, said in Los Angeles, ``There comes a time when a president must take action. That time has come.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the planning for a military strike ``had been in existence for some time. It was one of the first items I was briefed on'' when he took office last spring. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said of Noriega, ``As a practical matter, we have decapitated him from the dictatorship of this country and he is now a fugitive and will be treated as such. ... We will chase him and we will find him.'' At Bush's suggestion, Vice President Dan Quayle called the two newly installed Panamanian vice presidents, Billy Ford and Ricardo Arias Calderon, to congratulate them and say he looked forward to visiting them in a free and independent Panama, said a spokesman, David Beckwith. Quayle is considered likely to attend a presidential inauguration in Honduras on Jan. 27, and sources said a visit to Panama then is under consideration.
